flowRoot.flowPara: In collaborative mode, everyone can see what everyone else is doing. This mockup shows Eric's screen. Everyone else's would look similar, but each user can have different files open in a different arrangement.

Eric has two files open for editing: foo.js and bar.html. A color-coded background shows the cursor and/or selected text for all other collaborators who are also working on those files, in near-realtime. Mark's cursor is shown in foo.js, and Brian's cursor is shown in bar.html. Brian has selected a block of text in bar.html, a cue that he may be about to cut, delete, or indent it.

Mark also editing baz.js, but since Eric doesn't have baz.js open for editing, the file contents and details are not shown on Eric's screen. (If Eric's workspace becomes too cluttered, he has the option to hide closed files.)
Here, Eric has closed bar.html. It's still visible because Brian is working on it.
Eric has also opened baz.js, which Mark was already working on. Mark's current line and/or cursor is highlighted, as is Eric's current line and/or cursor.

baz.js invokes some functions that are defined in foo.js; those are shown in orange. This "layer" can be toggled on and off. Eric has it toggled on because he is working on code in both those sections. It could even be context-sensitive, based on the current line being edited; if the current line calls a function, the function call is visualized as a colored ribbon to its target. Otherwise, it's hidden.
